title: Football team blasted for axing little boys with disabilities
text:
Amadi Towe, 9, (left and center) and Kevin Blackman, 8, were kicked off their football team after they turned in their special education report cards. (Picture: Fox 61)

A football team has outraged parents by cutting two little boys with disabilities.

Eight-year-old Kevin Blackman and nine-year-old Amadi Towe were both kicked off their youth football team in New Haven, Connecticut last Wednesday.

Both boys also have learning disabilities and were axed from the team after their parents turned their Individualized Education Program report cards to league officials.

An IEP report card is a specialized education plan for a child with a disability in Connecticut. Both boys played in the Pop Warner football league, which is the only national youth sports league that requires children to prove they are doing well in school before they are permitted to play.

Towe’s mother, Mijija-ife Waters, told Fox 61 that after her son learned he was off the team, ‘(he) began to cry. He said he wished he was normal.’

‘I tried to explain to him, “You are normal. You just learn different,’ Waters said.

Waters later posted about her son’s removal from the team on Facebook, which is when Blackman’s mother, Sylvia Roman, realized her son was not alone.

Both parents said they were given vague explanations that their sons were removed from the team because of a ‘scholastic issue.’

However, Waters said league officials must not know what an IEP report card is – or that there are federal laws that prohibits discrimination based on disability.

She said: ‘Who ever (is) running this league, they need to do their homework, do their research. These kids are protected under the American Disabilities Act.’

Waters hit out at the league and accused it of discriminating against her son, despite federal laws that specify that children with disabilities must be given the same opportunity to play sports as anyone else. (Picture: Fox 61)

The American Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) specifically states that students with disabilities must have the same opportunities to participate in sports as anyone else.

Both boys’ families had already payed for their children to play for the entire season.

Reggie Lytle, who has been the president of the league for 22 years, said he was supposed to discuss the issue at a meeting with the league’s executive board, but the meeting was canceled.

Lytle said: ‘They refused to meet with me, I got a text canceling the meeting, I wanted to explain what an IEP is and some of the laws, but I never had the opportunity.’

The executive board has not yet commented on the matter.
